ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of keyword driven automation and an architecture of a framework for such testing.

X.T: When Should a Test Be Automated?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some ideas about the factors to be taken into account to decide for automated tests vs. manual tests.

X.T: Seven Steps to Test Automation Success

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of test automation with some very good practical comments.

X.T: Diagnosing Java code: Unit tests and automated code analysis working together
X.ST: Your tests can help your tools to analyze your code

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Unit tests and code analysis complete each other, but I am not sure the technologies are mature enough today to have an interesting return on investment when applied.
A personal evaluation of the cost of writing unit tests and their benefits.
A contract test verifies that a test double is still up-to-date with the real service it is simulating.

X.ST: Automate JavaScript code testing across browsers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to JSTestDriver.

X.T: Tools to unit test your JavaScript
X.ST: Using QUnit, YUI Test, and JSTestDriver

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of QUnit, YUI Test, and JSTestDriver.
Some pragmatic advice on writing tests, rather than blindly applying TDD.
A (late) answer to the previous blog entry.
A presentation of Venus.js and a demo of Venus.js and Mocha.

X.T: No more flaky tests on the Go team

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to fix a project where people got used to have flaky tests.

X.T: Rails Conf 2013 The Magic Tricks of Testing by Sandi Metz

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An effective simple explanation of the unit tests to be written and how to write them, based on query vs. command and incoming vs. internal vs. outgoing.

X.T: Your test suite is trying to tell you something

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An example of a flaky test which is in fact a real production bug.

X.T: Introducing Unit Testing in Legacy Code - Richard Blewett

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some techniques (introducing an interface, using Fakes…) to allow unit testing of legacy code.

X.T: Why Most Unit Testing is Waste

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An analysis of doing proper testing with some very surprising ideas: throw away tests that haven’t failed in a year, prefer integration tests to unit tests…
DHH debunks the fact that unit tests should not access the database because this would slow down too much their execution.
The advantages of having a test suite able to detect the most serious bugs.
The common traits of the different definitions of "unit tests", mocking or not the collaborators of the tested unit, duration of the test run and when to execute them.

X.T: Goto Fail, Heartbleed, and Unit Testing Culture

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After trying to convince the reader of the benefits of Unit Testing with demonstrating how the Goto Fail and Heartbleed bugs could have been avoided, MikeBland explains how the Unit Test culture has been introduced at Google and gives advice how to do the same in other companies. This is a pity that this article is much too long, the same message could have been expressed in a much shorter way.
The title says it all.
The author advises against using BDD automated tests.

X.T: Should tests be ordered or not?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author claims that tests can be ordered, but some arguments are biased (e.g. of course integration tests must be run after unit tests).

X.T: Testing Experimental Code in Production with Scientist.NET
X.ST: A .NET port of the Ruby library allows for experimental testing of code that's gone to production.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of Scientist, a library to compare the output of two different implementations.
Some obvious comments about unit testing from a newby.
A rather over-simplified description of the decoupling between the tests and the production code.

X.T: Why Do Programmers Fail to Write Good Unit Tests?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An opinion about the interest of unit tests and the characteristics of good ones.
The boundary between unit and integration tests is fuzzy.

X.T: What to test and not to test

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The ideas presented here are mostly common sense.
A list of principles to be considered for automated developer tests, their relative importance depends on the context.

X.ST: Are you repeating your unit tests in an effort to expect a different result?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An example of something that should not be tested: an exception thrown by a subsystem of the SUT and not managed by the SUT.

X.T: Applying Data Analytics to Test Automation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good advice for keeping and analysing automated test results, but this is too high-level and too few usage examples are given.
A list of tools to generate reports for automated tests.
TimBray’s opinion on automated tests (unit and integration tests).
Some advice to not use Gradient Boosting Trees to generate unit tests, but there is little information here.
Tests should be sensitive to the behaviour of the code being tested.

X.T: Test Desiderata 2/12 Tests Should be Structure-Insensitive

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tests should be insensitive to changes in the structure of the tested code.
Tests should read like a story.

X.T: Test Desiderata 4/12 Tests Should be Easy to Write

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tests should should be easy to write, otherwise this means the tested code has a design problem.

X.T: Test Desiderata 5/12: Tests Should be Fast

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tests should should be fast in order to not break the thinking flow.

X.T: Test Desiderata 6/12: Tests Should be Deterministic

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tests should should be deterministic, with an example of a flaky test.

X.T: Test Desiderata 7/12: Tests Should Be Automated

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tests should should be automated, there is a trade-off between automated tests and manual tests.

X.T: Test Desiderata 8/12: Tests Should Be Isolated (from each other)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tests should should use only locally initialised state or should leave the global state exactly as it was.

X.T: Test Desiderata 9/12 Tests Should Be Composable

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Production code should be composable, tests should also be, so there is no need to test the cross-product of some data combinations.

X.T: Test Desiderata 10/12: Tests Should be Specific

ARTICLE.COMMENT: When a given test fails, it should be obvious where the bug is in the production code.

X.T: Test Desiderata 11/12: Tests Should Predict Production

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Test Desiderata 12/12: Tests Should be Inspiring

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tests should inspire confidence.
A description on how to start with Moles, a framework to mock .NET methods.
Mock at the boundaries and write your own mocks.

BLIST.TITLE: The different types of test doubles

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The definitions of Dummy objects, Fake objects, Stub, Spies, and Mocks.
The differences between Dummy, Stub, Spy, Mock, and Fake.
A short description of using Mockito’s Answer.

X.T: Mockito Strict Stubbing and The UnnecessaryStubbingException

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Strict Stubbing and how to disable it.
A short description of PowerMockito, a PowerMock’s Mockito extension enabling to mock final, private or static methods.

This presentation presents some basic, but nevertheless interesting, ideas about strategies to determine if an automated test succeeded or failed: no oracle, true oracle, consistency, self-referential, and heuristic.

X.T: Testing with Simple and Combinatorial Oracles

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some ideas of oracles.

How to detect and fix issues in unit tests: code smells (tests difficult to understand, tests containing coding errors, tests difficult / impossible to write), behaviour smells (tests failing when they should succeed - erratic test, fragile test -, tests succeeding when they should fail), and project smells.
The two authors describe the return of investment of unit testing and propose their own tool for Java: JUnit.

X.T: Incremental development with Ant and JUnit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author describes how he used Ant for his build process, this one includes automatic unit tests with JUnit.
Some common testing errors: testing only the expected case, forgetting boundary situations, breaking encapsulation, and too much test complexity.
A detailed presentation of JUnit 5, describing the differences with JUnit 4 and giving a rational of the changes.

X.T: The top five reasons you should be using JUnit 5 right now!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of the most important improvements in JUnit 5.
The title says it all.

X.T: Know for Sure with Property-Based Testing
X.ST: How do you test your code against thousands of values?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to jqwik, a library to generate test data.

X.T: JUnit 5.6 Makes Testing Easy with New Features
X.ST: New features such as the ability to define test execution order and run tests in parallel make this an important release.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some features added since JUnit 5.0: order of execution, defining timeouts, conditional test execution, programmatic extensions, and running tests in parallel.

X.ST: Temporary files are frequently used in testing and in production. Here is how to create and manage—and delete—them.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic information about temporary files in JUnit 4, JUnit 5, and plain Java.
A short presentation of @Nested classes.

X.T: Guide to Dynamic Tests in Junit 5

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of dynamic tests.

X.T: Writing Templates for Test Cases Using JUnit 5

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A too short presentation of test templates.
A description of repeated tests.
A short explanation and example of nested tests.

X.T: Test Parameterization With JUnit 5.7: A Deep Dive Into @EnumSource
X.ST: @EnumSource makes an impression of an esoteric device that can hardly feel useful. Though, for the right problem, they are priceless. Find out where they shine.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of @EnumSource.
How to use @TempDir.
A description of JUnit 4 and 5 assertions, some are not clearly explained.
An exhaustive description of parametrised tests.

X.T: Make your Selenium Test Results Live using Grafana & InfluxDB

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Despite the title, this article is about integrating TestNG results in real time in InfluxDB and display them in Grafana.

X.ST: Discover a couple of tips and tricks for writing better unit tests with the AssertJ framework. Every recommendation includes a practical demonstration.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Go-Fuzz and some advice on how to use it.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some generalities about performance testing of Web applications: description of the different types of performances tests, architecture of a performance test environment, in-house vs. vendor vs. open source performance tools, keeping all the data for a while…
After describing what is negligence and malpractice, explaining that tests must be prioritised depending on the risks, CemKaner gives a list of coverage measures as some food for thought.
